column4: Okay... well.. I was just trying to install a VIM plugin/script for svn/cvs integration -- and it requires vim 7
if you fancy converting, Emacs' support for SVN is damn good
you're probably right, it took me a while to get used to it too
similar kind of thing in Emacs, and it's trivial to setup a defun/bind for an interactive function that would diff the current file against version-n, and output it to another buffer
* If I move to some part of code, hitting a key to show me, to the side, the previous version and the differences -- another key would go another version back.
but showing it kind of to the side
sure, just split the window horizontally
tiny 8 line emacs-lisp script to setup those windows
not to be too irritating -- but why is the windows emacs subdir (http://ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/emacs/windows/) having files that are tar.gz'ed?
probably because they're free, and can easily be decompressed on windows :)
do you guys code in windows?
I'd like to write a small C program in windows sometime.  I've not done coding in MS stuff since DOS days, and a couple visual basic programs.
